content: The "Capital Gains Reform Act of 1997" is also known as the "70-Percent Capital Gains Deduction for Taxpayers Other Than Corporations." This Act amends Section 1202 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to provide a capital gains deduction. The Capital Gains Reform Act of 1997, also known as the 70-Percent Capital Gains Deduction for Taxpayers Other Than Corporations, allows taxpayers other than corporations to deduct 70 percent of their net capital gain from gross income. This deduction applies to estates and trusts as well, with specific rules for calculating the deduction. Additionally, the net capital gain is reduced by the amount considered as investment income under section 163(d)(4)(B)(iii) for coordination with the treatment of capital gain under the limitation on investment interest. The transitional rule under section 163(d)(4)(B)(iii) limits the net capital gain taken into account for taxable years including January 1 after the enactment date. This rule also reduces the net capital gain for applying section 1(h) and includes special rules for pass-thru entities. The determination of gains and losses for pass-thru entities is made at the entity level. A pass-thru entity includes regulated investment companies, real estate investment trusts, S corporations, partnerships, estates or trusts, and common trust funds. Additionally, a new deduction is allowable in computing adjusted gross income under the Internal Revenue Code. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow a new deduction for long-term capital gains. Various sections of the Code are also amended to reflect this change, including the removal of subsection (h) in Section 1 and adjustments to sections 170(e)(1), 172(d)(2)(B), and 453A(c)(3) regarding the deduction under section 1202. Amendments include changes to sections 1402(i)(1), 1445(e), and 7518(g)(6)(A) regarding deductions and tax rates. Amendments are made to sections 7518(g)(6)(A) and 607(h)(6)(A) of the Internal Revenue Code, adjusting tax rates from 28 percent to 15.6 percent and 34 percent to 22 percent. Additionally, the item related to section 1202 in the table of sections is amended. The amendments made by section 1202 apply to taxable years ending after December 31 of the year of enactment, with specific effective dates for different provisions. The amendments made by subsection (c)(12) apply to amounts paid on or after January 1 of the year following the date of enactment of this Act. SEC. 3. REDUCTION OF ALTERNATIVE CAPITAL GAIN TAX FOR CORPORATIONS. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to reduce the alternative tax rate for corporations from 35 percent to 22 percent. A transitional rule is also introduced to limit net capital gain for taxable years following the enactment of the subsection. Additionally, a special rule for pass-thru entities is included. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to change the tax rate for corporations from 35 percent to 22 percent. A special rule for pass-thru entities is introduced, and a specific section of the Code is adjusted by changing the percentage from 65 percent to 78 percent for taxable years ending after December 31 of the year of enactment.
